Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: An angry client is loudly criticising a cut moments before the salon is due to close.
Story: The phone in my pocket buzzes insistently, and I know it’s my mom. It’s Sunday evening, our weekly call time. She’ll be waiting, probably already worrying if I don’t pick up soon. But right now, I’m standing in the salon, scissors still in hand, facing a client whose voice is rising with every word. She’s furious about her haircut, gesturing at the mirror, demanding I fix it before she leaves. The other stylists are packing up, glancing at me with sympathy as the clock ticks past closing. My mind races—if I answer my mom, I’ll be distracted and the client will feel ignored, maybe even angrier. But if I focus on the client, I’ll miss my call, and my mom will be hurt, maybe think I’m too busy for her. I feel pulled in two directions, my heart pounding as I try to figure out how to be a good child and a good hairdresser at the same time.
